articles.headline: Iraqi Assails U.S. for Strikes on Civilians
articles.snippet: The prime minister of Iraq said that U.S. troops crush civilians "with their vehicles and kill them just on suspicion."
articles.abstract: The prime minister of Iraq said that U.S. troops crush civilians "with their vehicles and kill them just on suspicion."

articles.headline: The Gauls at Home in Erin
articles.snippet: European countries have to deal not only with immigration from places like Africa and Southeast Asia, but also from their neighbors in the European Union.
articles.abstract: European countries have to deal not only with immigration from places like Africa and Southeast Asia, but also from their neighbors in the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN  This snug Irish capital might seem an unlikely destination for young French men and women. The weather would jar anyone from the Côte d'Azur. And the food is basically what the Michelin restaurant guide might consider a form of boiled stew.

articles.headline: Asian Cars Won 40% of Market Last Month
articles.snippet: Sales of fuel-efficient vehicles like the Toyota Corolla, Honda Civic and Hyundai Sonata all rose 20 percent or more compared with May 2005.
articles.abstract: Sales of fuel-efficient vehicles like the Toyota Corolla, Honda Civic and Hyundai Sonata all rose 20 percent or more compared with May 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 1 — Three decades ago, with fuel supplies running short and long gas lines around the corner, Asian cars won their first converts in the American market.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Army Builders Accept Blame Over Flooding
articles.snippet: A report has concluded that New Orleans's levees were not built for a storm as strong as Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: A report has concluded that New Orleans's levees were not built for a storm as strong as Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sweeping new study of the causes of the disaster in New Orleans last year, the Army Corps of Engineers concludes that the levees it built in the city were an incomplete patchwork of protection, containing flaws in design and construction and not built to handle a storm anywhere near the strength of Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: Which Bosses Really Care if Shares Rise?
articles.snippet: Investors should know how much the executive's wealth will rise if the stock goes up, and how much it will fall if the stock goes down.
articles.abstract: Investors should know how much the executive's wealth will rise if the stock goes up, and how much it will fall if the stock goes down.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHY do we want to know all the perks, pensions and privileges of corporate chieftains? That is a question the Securities and Exchange Commission should be considering as it figures out how much additional disclosure to require.

articles.headline: Iraqi Assails U.S. for Strikes on Civilians
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki lashed out at the American military on Thursday, denouncing what he characterized as habitual attacks by troops against Iraqi civilians.     As outrage over reports that American marines killed 24 Iraqis in the ...
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki lashed out at the American military on Thursday, denouncing what he characterized as habitual attacks by troops against Iraqi civilians.     As outrage over reports that American marines killed 24 Iraqis in the town of Haditha last year continued to shake the new government, the country's senior leaders said that they would demand that American officials turn over their investigative files on the killings and that the Iraqi government would conduct its own inquiry.

articles.headline: A Seamless Major Domo, on Wall St. or in Washington
articles.snippet: As Henry M. Paulson Jr. pondered whether to leave the job he loves at Goldman Sachs for a new position of uncertain power at the Treasury, he received some crucial advice earlier last month from James A. Baker III, a Treasury secretary in the admi...
articles.abstract: As Henry M. Paulson Jr. pondered whether to leave the job he loves at Goldman Sachs for a new position of uncertain power at the Treasury, he received some crucial advice earlier last month from James A. Baker III, a Treasury secretary in the administration of President Ronald Reagan.     It is not every day that a Wall Street chief executive gets career counseling from a Washington power broker like Mr. Baker. But for Mr. Paulson, the words of wisdom represented a payoff of sorts from a series of relationships he has forged with Washington insiders through the counsel of his chief of staff and closest adviser at Goldman Sachs, John F. W. Rogers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Henry M. Paulson Jr. pondered whether to leave the job he loves at Goldman Sachs for a new position of uncertain power at the Treasury, he received some crucial advice earlier last month from James A. Baker III, a Treasury secretary in the administration of President Ronald Reagan.

articles.headline: The Gauls at Home in Erin; Opportunity Knocks in Ireland, and the French Answer
articles.snippet: This snug Irish capital might seem an unlikely destination for young French men and women. The weather would jar anyone from the Côte d'Azur. And the food is basically what the Michelin restaurant guide might consider a form of boiled stew.      Y...
articles.abstract: This snug Irish capital might seem an unlikely destination for young French men and women. The weather would jar anyone from the Côte d'Azur. And the food is basically what the Michelin restaurant guide might consider a form of boiled stew.      Yet thousands of people -- many just out of university -- are deserting France to live and work here, in a European city that sparkles with economic vibrancy despite a more general sense of stagnation in much of the Continent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN - This snug Irish capital might seem an unlikely destination for young French men and women. The weather would jar anyone from the Côte d'Azur. And the food is basically what the Michelin restaurant guide might consider a form of boiled stew.

articles.headline: Asian Cars Won 40% of Market Last Month
articles.snippet: Three decades ago, with fuel supplies running short and long gas lines around the corner, Asian cars won their first converts in the American market.     Now that average gas prices are flirting with $3 a gallon, consumers are rushing to them agai...
articles.abstract: Three decades ago, with fuel supplies running short and long gas lines around the corner, Asian cars won their first converts in the American market.     Now that average gas prices are flirting with $3 a gallon, consumers are rushing to them again.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 1 - Three decades ago, with fuel supplies running short and long gas lines around the corner, Asian cars won their first converts in the American market.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Army Builders Accept Blame Over Flooding
articles.snippet: In a sweeping new study of the causes of the disaster in New Orleans last year, the Army Corps of Engineers concludes that the levees it built in the city were an incomplete patchwork of protection, containing flaws in design and construction and ...
articles.abstract: In a sweeping new study of the causes of the disaster in New Orleans last year, the Army Corps of Engineers concludes that the levees it built in the city were an incomplete patchwork of protection, containing flaws in design and construction and not built to handle a storm anywhere near the strength of Hurricane Katrina.      ''The hurricane protection system in New Orleans and southeast Louisiana was a system in name only,'' said the draft of the nine-volume report, released yesterday in New Orleans.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sweeping new study of the causes of the disaster in New Orleans last year, the Army Corps of Engineers concludes that the levees it built in the city were an incomplete patchwork of protection, containing flaws in design and construction and not built to handle a storm anywhere near the strength of Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: Which Bosses Really Care if Shares Rise?
articles.snippet: WHY do we want to know all the perks, pensions and privileges of corporate chieftains? That is a question the Securities and Exchange Commission should be considering as it figures out how much additional disclosure to require.     The answer for ...
articles.abstract: WHY do we want to know all the perks, pensions and privileges of corporate chieftains? That is a question the Securities and Exchange Commission should be considering as it figures out how much additional disclosure to require.     The answer for many is a hope that somehow the full disclosure will shame corporate boards and bosses into cutting back on excessive pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHY do we want to know all the perks, pensions and privileges of corporate chieftains? That is a question the Securities and Exchange Commission should be considering as it figures out how much additional disclosure to require.

articles.headline: NASD Ends Case Against Quattrone
articles.snippet: Frank P. Quattrone, the most prominent banker in Silicon Valley during the 1990's technology boom, won a third major legal battle yesterday as securities industry regulators dropped all charges against him.      The decision comes just two months ...
articles.abstract: Frank P. Quattrone, the most prominent banker in Silicon Valley during the 1990's technology boom, won a third major legal battle yesterday as securities industry regulators dropped all charges against him.      The decision comes just two months after a federal appeals court overturned his conviction on charges of obstruction of justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission reversed a decision to ban him for life from the securities industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frank P. Quattrone, the most prominent banker in Silicon Valley during the 1990's technology boom, won a third major legal battle yesterday as securities industry regulators dropped all charges against him.
